lesson_title: Listening to Instructions: Understanding What to Do
objectives: Learn to listen carefully and understand spoken words and instructions.
Practice following simple and multi-step instructions from teachers or elders.
Improve understanding of common commands used in the classroom and at home.

sections.text: Listening is one of the most important skills in learning. When you listen carefully, you understand what the teacher wants you to do, what your parents tell you, or what your friends are saying. Good listening helps you learn better, avoid mistakes, and do things correctly.

examples.label: In Class
examples.value: Your teacher explains a new lesson. If you listen carefully, you will understand it better.

examples.label: At Home
examples.value: Your mother tells you to bring water. If you listen, you will bring water quickly and correctly.

examples.label: Playing Games
examples.value: In a game, your friend tells you the rules. If you listen, you will play correctly.

usage_examples: Always **listen carefully** to your teacher's instructions.
Good **listening** helps you finish your work correctly.
When you listen, you learn new things easily.
My father said, 'Listen to me when I talk.'
Listening is the first step to speaking good English.

sections.text: These are common things your teacher might ask you to do with your books, notebooks, and papers.

examples.label: Open your books.
examples.value: To open your textbook or notebook to a certain page.

examples.label: Close your books.
examples.value: To shut your textbook or notebook.

examples.label: Turn to page...
examples.value: To find a specific page number in your book. Example: 'Turn to page 15.'

examples.label: Write your name.
examples.value: To put your name on your paper or notebook.

examples.label: Read aloud.
examples.value: To read the text loudly so everyone can hear.

usage_examples: Teacher: '**Open your books** to page number ten.'
Class is over. '**Close your books**, please.'
She asked me to '**turn to page 25**'.
Before submitting, '**write your name** on the paper.'
The teacher asked Ram to '**read aloud** the story.'
**Look at the picture** on page seven.
**Underline the important words**.

sections.text: These are common instructions about moving around or doing actions in the classroom or elsewhere.

examples.label: Stand up.
examples.value: To rise from a sitting position to a standing position.

examples.label: Sit down.
examples.value: To move from a standing position to a sitting position.

examples.label: Come here.
examples.value: To ask someone to move closer to you.

examples.label: Go there.
examples.value: To ask someone to move to a specific place away from you.

examples.label: Look at the board.
examples.value: To direct your eyes towards the blackboard.

examples.label: Listen carefully.
examples.value: To pay close attention with your ears.

usage_examples: When the teacher enters, '**stand up**', please.
After the assembly, '**sit down** in your seats.'
Teacher: '**Come here**, Rahul, and show me your book.'
He told me to '**go there** and get the chalk.'
Everyone, **look at the board**; I am writing something.
Please **listen carefully** to my instructions.
**Raise your hand** if you have a question.
**Don't talk** during the class.

sections.text: These are general commands used by teachers to manage the class and ensure smooth learning.

examples.label: Be quiet.
examples.value: To stop making noise or talking.

examples.label: Pay attention.
examples.value: To focus your mind and eyes on what is being taught or said.

examples.label: Repeat after me.
examples.value: To say the same words or phrase that the teacher just said.

examples.label: Work in groups.
examples.value: To work together with a few classmates.

examples.label: Don't touch that.
examples.value: To warn someone not to touch something.

usage_examples: Class, **be quiet**, please! I am going to start.
Everyone, **pay attention** to the new lesson.
Teacher: 'Apple.' Students: '**Repeat after me**: Apple.'
For this activity, you will **work in groups**.
**Don't touch that** hot pot!
**Share your ideas** with your partner.
**Come to the front** of the class.

sections.text: One-step instructions are simple commands that ask you to do only one thing.

examples.label: Instruction
examples.value: Drink water.

examples.label: Instruction
examples.value: Open the window.

examples.label: Instruction
examples.value: Close the door.

examples.label: Instruction
examples.value: Give me the book.

usage_examples: Teacher: '**Stand up**.' (Student stands up)
Mother: '**Bring water**.' (Child brings water)
Friend: '**Pass the ball**.' (You pass the ball)
**Sit down**, please.
**Eat your food**.

sections.text: Multi-step instructions ask you to do two or more things in order. It's important to listen to all parts of the instruction before you start.

examples.label: Two Steps
examples.value: **Stand up** and **come to the board**.

examples.label: Three Steps
examples.value: **Open your books**, **turn to page 15**, and **read the first paragraph**.

examples.label: Daily Life Example
examples.value: **Go to the well**, **fill the bucket**, and **bring it home**.

usage_examples: Teacher: '**Take out your notebooks** and **write today's date**.'
Mother: '**Go to the market**, **buy vegetables**, and **come back soon**.'
Friend: '**Pick up the ball** and **throw it to me**.'
Listen to all the steps carefully, then start the work.
First, do this, then do that.
**Clean your room** and **then play outside**.

sections.text:
To be a good listener, you need to do more than just hear the sounds. You need to actively understand. 
1. **Look at the person who is speaking**. 
2. **Don't talk when others are talking**. 
3. **Think about what they are saying**. 
4. **Ask questions if you don't understand**.

examples.label: Look at the Speaker
examples.value: When your teacher speaks, look at her face. This helps you focus.

examples.label: Don't Interrupt
examples.value: Wait for the person to finish talking before you speak.

examples.label: Think and Understand
examples.value: As they speak, try to make a picture in your mind of what they are saying.

examples.label: Ask Questions
examples.value: If you are confused, politely ask: 'Can you repeat that, please?' or 'I don't understand.'

usage_examples: Always **look at the teacher** when she gives instructions.
It's polite not to **interrupt** when someone is talking.
Try to **understand the meaning** of every instruction.
If you don't know, **ask questions**.
Good listeners always pay **attention**.
Listening carefully helps you to learn English faster.
